question_text: Question
option_d: Answer

question_text: What is Unreal Engine?
option_d: Unreal Engine is a powerful
correct_answer: open-source game engine developed by Epic Games
mdn_link: and interactive experiences across multiple platforms.

question_text: What programming language does Unreal Engine primarily use?
option_d: Unreal Engine primarily uses C++ for programming
correct_answer: along with Blueprints (a visual scripting system) for rapid prototyping and gameplay logic.

question_text: What are Blueprints?
option_d: Blueprints are Unreal Engine's visual scripting system that allows developers to create gameplay logic
explanation: and systems without writing traditional code

question_text: What is an Actor in Unreal Engine?
option_d: An Actor is any object that can be placed in a level
topic: or player start. All Actors support 3D transformations (translation
youtube_english: scale) and can be spawned/destroyed at runtime.

question_text: What is a Component in Unreal Engine?
option_d: A Component is a piece of functionality that can be added to an Actor. Components are modular and reusable—for example
correct_answer: a Spot Light Component or a Movement Component.

question_text: What is a Level?
option_d: A Level (or Map) is a gameplay area that contains Actors
explanation: and gameplay elements. A game typically consists of multiple Levels.

question_text: What is the Viewport?
option_d: The Viewport is the main 3D editing window where you can view and manipulate your Level. It provides tools for moving

question_text: What is the World Outliner?
option_d: The World Outliner is a panel that lists all Actors in the current Level. It helps you select

question_text: What is the Content Browser?
option_d: The Content Browser is where you manage all your project's assets (meshes
mdn_link: etc.). It mirrors your project's file structure on disk.

question_text: What is the Details Panel?
option_d: The Details Panel shows properties of the selected Actor or asset. Here you can edit settings like transformation

question_text: How do you create a new Blueprint?
option_c: Right-click in the Content Browser → Blueprint Class → choose a parent class (e.g.
option_d: Actor
explanation: Character). Give it a name and double-click to open the Blueprint Editor.

question_text: What are the main tabs in the Blueprint Editor?
option_d: The Blueprint Editor has several tabs: Event Graph (for logic)

question_text: What is the Event Graph in Blueprints?
option_d: The Event Graph is where you create gameplay logic by connecting nodes (events
explanation: variables) together. Events (like Event BeginPlay) trigger the execution of connected nodes.

question_text: What is Event BeginPlay?
option_d: Event BeginPlay is a Blueprint event that triggers once when the Actor is spawned or when gameplay begins in the Level. It's commonly used for initialization.

question_text: What is Event Tick?
option_d: Event Tick is a Blueprint event that triggers every frame. Use it for logic that needs continuous updates (like movement). Be mindful of performance.

question_text: How do you create a variable in Blueprints?
option_d: In the My Blueprint tab
correct_answer: click the "+ Variable" button. Set its name
youtube_hindi: and optionally default value. You can make it public (editable) or private.

question_text: What is a Static Mesh?
option_d: A Static Mesh is a piece of geometry that consists of a set of polygons that cannot be animated vertex-wise (but can be moved/rotated as a whole). Used for walls

question_text: What is a Skeletal Mesh?
option_d: A Skeletal Mesh is a mesh that is bound to a skeleton (bone hierarchy) and can be deformed for animation. Used for characters

question_text: What is a Material?
option_d: A Material defines the surface properties of a mesh—how it reacts to light
mdn_link: etc. It is created using a node-based Material Editor.

question_text: What is a Texture?
option_d: A Texture is a 2D image applied to a 3D surface to give it color
topic: or other surface attributes. Textures are often used as inputs to Materials.

question_text: How do you apply a Material to a Static Mesh?
option_d: Select the Static Mesh in the Viewport or World Outliner. In the Details Panel
correct_answer: find the Materials section. Click the dropdown and select a Material asset.

question_text: What is a Pawn?
option_d: A Pawn is an Actor that can be "possessed" (controlled) by a Player Controller or AI Controller. It represents the physical presence of a player or AI in the world.

question_text: What is a Character?
option_d: A Character is a specialized Pawn that includes a Capsule Component for collision
correct_answer: a Character Movement Component for walking/flying/swimming

question_text: What is a Player Controller?
option_d: A Player Controller manages player input and camera. Each player has a Player Controller
correct_answer: which can possess a Pawn to control it.

question_text: What is the Game Mode?
option_d: The Game Mode defines the game's rules
mdn_link: and win conditions. There is one Game Mode per Level.

question_text: How do you set the Game Mode for a Level?
option_d: Go to Settings → World Settings. Under Game Mode
correct_answer: set "GameMode Override" to your desired Game Mode Blueprint.

question_text: What is a Collision in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Collision refers to the detection and response when two objects (with collision geometry) touch or overlap. Unreal uses collision channels and responses to control interactions.

question_text: What are Collision Presets?
option_d: Collision Presets are predefined sets of collision responses (Block

question_text: What is the difference between Block and Overlap collision?
option_d: Block prevents objects from passing through each other (physical collision). Overlap allows objects to pass through but triggers overlap events (OnBeginOverlap

question_text: How do you add a collision to a Static Mesh?
option_d: In the Static Mesh Editor
correct_answer: you can add collision via menu: Collision → Add Box/Sphere/Capsule Simplified Collision
explanation: or use Auto Convex Collision for complex shapes.

question_text: What is the OnBeginOverlap event?
option_d: OnBeginOverlap is a Blueprint event that triggers when an Actor's collision component begins overlapping with another component (if collision is set to Overlap).

question_text: What is the OnHit event (for Block collisions)?
option_d: OnHit (or Event Hit) triggers when a physics object (with simulation enabled) collides with another object with Block response. It provides impact data like normal and impulse.

question_text: What is a Trigger Volume?
option_d: A Trigger Volume is a Box/Sphere/Capsule-shaped invisible volume that can generate overlap events. It's often used to detect when a player enters an area.

question_text: How do you create a Trigger Volume?
option_d: In the Place Actors panel
explanation: drag "Trigger Box" or "Trigger Sphere" into the Level. Adjust its size in the Details Panel.

question_text: What is a Light Actor?
option_d: A Light Actor is an Actor that emits light into the scene. Types include Directional Light

question_text: What is a Directional Light?
option_d: A Directional Light simulates light coming from an infinitely far source (like the sun). It casts parallel shadows and affects the entire Level.

question_text: What is a Point Light?
option_d: A Point Light emits light equally in all directions from a single point (like a light bulb).

question_text: What is a Spot Light?
option_d: A Spot Light emits light in a cone shape
correct_answer: like a flashlight or stage spotlight.

question_text: What is the purpose of Build Lighting?
option_d: Build Lighting calculates static lighting and shadows and bakes them into lightmaps. It's necessary for static lights to appear correctly. Press "Build" (lightning bolt icon) or use Build → Build Lighting Only.

question_text: What is a Camera Actor?
option_d: A Camera Actor is an Actor that defines a view into the world. You can place multiple cameras and switch between them.

question_text: How do you set the active view to a Camera Actor?
option_d: Select the Camera Actor
explanation: or right-click in the Viewport and choose "Active Camera View". To revert

question_text: What is a Timeline in Blueprints?
option_d: A Timeline is a Blueprint node that allows you to animate values (floats
explanation: colors) over time using keyframes. Useful for simple animations like doors opening.

question_text: How do you create a Timeline in Blueprints?
option_d: Right-click in the Event Graph → Add Timeline. Double-click the Timeline node to open its editor
correct_answer: where you add tracks and keyframes.

question_text: What is the Play button in the Editor?
option_d: The Play button (▶) starts a play-in-editor (PIE) session
correct_answer: allowing you to test your game directly in the Editor. You can also use Simulate (for AI testing) or VR Preview.

question_text: What is the difference between Play and Simulate?
option_d: Play uses a Player Controller and simulates player input. Simulate does not use a Player Controller—the character is controlled as if by AI (useful for testing AI behavior).

question_text: How do you save your Level?
option_d: File → Save Current (Ctrl+S)
correct_answer: or click the Save icon in the toolbar. You can also use File → Save All to save everything.

question_text: What is the purpose of the Folders in Content Browser?
option_d: Folders help organize your assets. Right-click in Content Browser → New Folder. Good practice to create folders like Meshes

question_text: How do you import assets into Unreal Engine?
option_d: In Content Browser
explanation: or drag and drop files from Windows Explorer. Supported formats include FBX

question_text: What is a Blueprint Function?
option_d: A Blueprint Function is a reusable block of nodes that can be called from other parts of the same Blueprint. It can have inputs

question_text: How do you create a Blueprint Function?
option_d: In the My Blueprint tab
correct_answer: click "+ Function". Give it a name and double-click to open its graph. Add inputs/outputs via the Details Panel.

question_text: What is a Blueprint Macro?
option_d: A Blueprint Macro is a container for a group of nodes that can be reused within a single Blueprint. Unlike Functions
correct_answer: Macros are expanded inline (copy-pasted) and cannot have return values.

question_text: When should you use a Function vs a Macro?
option_d: Use a Function when you need reusable logic with return values
correct_answer: or that will be called from multiple Blueprints. Use a Macro for simple node groups used only within one Blueprint
explanation: especially if you want to avoid function call overhead.

question_text: What is the Construction Script in Blueprints?
option_d: The Construction Script runs when the Blueprint is placed in the Level or when its properties are changed in the Editor. It's used for visual updates (like procedural meshes).

question_text: Why would you use the Construction Script instead of Event BeginPlay?
option_d: Use Construction Script for logic that should update in the Editor (like adjusting a building's height visually). Use Event BeginPlay for runtime-only logic (like spawning enemies).

question_text: How do you move an Actor using Blueprints?
option_d: Use the "Set Actor Location" node (or "Add Actor World Offset") in the Event Graph. Typically you'd call this every tick or on an event.

question_text: How do you rotate an Actor using Blueprints?
option_d: Use the "Set Actor Rotation" node (or "Add Actor World Rotation"). Provide a Rotator (pitch

question_text: What is a Rotator in Unreal Engine?
option_d: A Rotator is a struct that represents a rotation with three float components: Pitch (rotation around X-axis)

question_text: What is a Vector in Unreal Engine?
option_d: A Vector is a struct with X
explanation: Z float components. Used for positions
youtube_english: and colors (as LinearColor). Common types: FVector (3D)

question_text: What is Delta Time?
option_d: Delta Time (often obtained via "Get World Delta Seconds") is the time in seconds since the last frame. Multiplying movement by Delta Time makes it framerate-independent.

question_text: Why is Delta Time important for movement?
option_d: Using Delta Time ensures that movement speed remains consistent regardless of framerate. Without it
correct_answer: faster computers would have faster gameplay.

question_text: How do you get player input in Blueprints?
option_d: Use Input Events (like "InputAxis MoveForward" or "Action Mappings") by enabling them in Project Settings → Input. Then
explanation: right-click and search for the input event.

question_text: How do you set up Input Actions in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Go to Edit → Project Settings → Input. Under Bindings
correct_answer: add Action Mappings (for discrete actions like Jump) and Axis Mappings (for continuous input like movement).

question_text: What is an Action Mapping?
option_d: An Action Mapping is for discrete inputs like button presses (e.g.
explanation: Fire). It returns a boolean (pressed/released) and can have multiple keys bound.

question_text: What is an Axis Mapping?
option_d: An Axis Mapping is for continuous inputs like joystick or mouse movement. It returns a float value (e.g.
correct_answer: -1 to 1) representing the intensity of input.

question_text: How do you spawn an Actor at runtime?
option_d: Use the "Spawn Actor from Class" node. Provide a class (Blueprint)
explanation: and optionally a spawn parameters struct.

question_text: How do you destroy an Actor at runtime?
option_d: Use the "Destroy Actor" node on the Actor you want to destroy. It will be removed from the Level.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Get Actor Location" node?
option_d: Get Actor Location returns the world-space position (as a Vector) of the Actor. Useful for calculations like distance.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Get Player Controller" node?
option_d: Get Player Controller returns a reference to the Player Controller. Useful for accessing player input

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Get Controlled Pawn" node?
option_d: Get Controlled Pawn returns the Pawn currently possessed by the Player Controller. Useful in the Player Controller's Blueprint.

question_text: What is a Widget Blueprint?
option_d: A Widget Blueprint is a Blueprint for creating UI elements (HUD
topic: text). It uses a visual designer and event graph for UI logic.

question_text: How do you create a Widget Blueprint?
option_d: In Content Browser
correct_answer: right-click → User Interface → Widget Blueprint. Name it and double-click to open the Widget Designer.

question_text: How do you display a Widget on screen?
option_d: In a Blueprint
correct_answer: use "Create Widget" to create an instance
explanation: then "Add to Viewport" (or "Add to Player Screen") to show it. Usually done in the Player Controller or HUD.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Bind" feature for Widget variables?
option_d: Binding a widget variable (like Text Block's Text) to a function allows the UI to update automatically when the underlying data changes

question_text: How do you play a sound in Blueprints?
option_d: Use the "Play Sound at Location" node (for 3D sounds) or "Play Sound 2D" (for UI/music). Provide a Sound Wave asset.

question_text: What is a Sound Cue?
option_d: A Sound Cue is a Blueprint-like asset for creating complex audio behaviors by connecting nodes (like attenuations

question_text: What is a Particle System (Niagara)?
option_d: Niagara is Unreal's advanced particle effects system (replacing Cascade). It allows creation of complex visual effects like fire

question_text: How do you create a simple Niagara particle system?
option_d: In Content Browser
correct_answer: right-click → FX → Niagara System. Choose a template (like "Fountain") and edit in the Niagara Editor.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Print String" node?
option_d: Print String displays a message on screen (and optionally to the log) for debugging. Useful for checking variable values or confirming event triggers.

question_text: How do you add a breakpoint in Blueprints?
option_d: Right-click on a node and choose "Add Breakpoint". When the game hits that node during PIE
correct_answer: execution will pause and you can inspect values.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Branch" node?
option_d: Branch is a conditional node (if-then-else). It takes a Boolean input (Condition) and executes either the True or False output.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Sequence" node?
option_d: Sequence executes its output pins in order (Then 0
explanation: etc.). Useful for organizing linear flow without connecting many wires.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "ForLoop" node?
option_d: ForLoop executes its loop body a specified number of times. It provides an index (current iteration) and can break early.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Delay" node?
option_d: Delay pauses execution for a specified duration (in seconds) before continuing. It does not block other events (it's latent).

question_text: Why should you avoid using too many Delay nodes in a row?
option_d: Using many sequential Delays can create hard-to-read spaghetti logic and may cause timing issues. Consider using Timelines or State Machines for complex timed sequences.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Gate" node?
option_d: Gate is a flow control node that can be opened
explanation: or toggled. It allows or blocks execution flow based on external input.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Do Once" node?
option_d: Do Once allows a sequence to execute only once unless reset. Useful for one-time initialization or actions.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "FlipFlop" node?
option_d: FlipFlop alternates between two outputs (A and B) each time it's triggered. Useful for toggling states.

question_text: How do you cast to another Blueprint class?
option_d: Use the "Cast To" node. Drag a wire from an object reference
correct_answer: search for "Cast To [ClassName]". If the cast succeeds

question_text: Why is casting used in Blueprints?
option_d: Casting is used to access specific functionality of a child class when you have a reference to a parent class. For example
correct_answer: casting a Pawn to your custom Character to access health variables.

question_text: What is an Interface in Unreal Engine?
option_d: An Interface defines a set of functions that can be implemented by different Blueprint classes
correct_answer: allowing communication between unrelated classes without casting.

question_text: When should you use an Interface instead of Casting?
option_d: Use an Interface when multiple unrelated classes need to share common functionality (e.g.
correct_answer: "Damagable" interface for both enemies and objects). It reduces tight coupling compared to casting.

question_text: What is a Data Asset?
option_d: A Data Asset is a Blueprintable asset that stores data (like stats
correct_answer: item properties) without logic. Useful for configurable game data.

question_text: What is a Data Table?
option_d: A Data Table is an asset that stores structured data (rows and columns) imported from CSV or JSON. Useful for large datasets like item databases.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Save Game" system?
option_d: The Save Game system allows you to save and load game state (player progress
explanation: etc.) to disk. You create a Save Game Blueprint to define what data to store.

question_text: How do you create a Save Game Blueprint?
option_d: Create a Blueprint Class based on "SaveGame". Add variables to store data. Use "Create Save Game Object" and "Save Game to Slot" to save.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Project Settings"?
option_d: Project Settings contain global configurations for your project

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Packaging" project settings?
option_d: Packaging settings configure how your project is built into an executable for distribution. Includes settings like project name

question_text: How do you package (build) your game?
option_d: File → Package Project → choose a platform (Windows
explanation: etc.) → select an output folder. Unreal will compile and create an executable.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Maps & Modes" project settings?
option_d: This defines the default map loaded when the game starts (Game Default Map) and the default Game Mode used if none is specified in a Level.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Game Instance"?
option_d: The Game Instance is a persistent object that exists for the entire game session (across level changes). It's useful for managing global state like player profiles or online sessions.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Game State"?
option_d: The Game State holds game-wide information that should be replicated to all clients in a multiplayer game

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Player State"?
option_d: Player State holds player-specific information that should be replicated
topic: kills/deaths. Each player has their own Player State.

question_text: What is the purpose of "Replication" in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Replication is the process of synchronizing data and function calls from the server to clients in a multiplayer game. Essential for making multiplayer games work.

question_text: What is the most important concept in Unreal Engine for beginners?
option_d: Component
correct_answer: Understanding that everything in a Level is an Actor
explanation: and Actors get their functionality from Components
topic: is the most fundamental concept for Unreal Engine beginners.

question_text: Why is Unreal Engine popular for AAA game development?
option_d: Unreal Engine is popular for AAA games due to its high-quality graphics (ray tracing
youtube_hindi: and strong support from Epic Games.

question_text: When should you use Blueprints vs C++ in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Use Blueprints for rapid prototyping
explanation: and simple gameplay logic. Use C++ for performance-critical systems
mdn_link: and engine modifications. Many projects use both.

question_text: How do you optimize performance in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Use the Profiler (Stat commands)
youtube_english: and avoid expensive operations in Tick. Also
youtube_hindi: use Blueprint nativization for critical Blueprints.

question_text: What is the purpose of the "Stat" commands in the console?
option_d: Stat commands (like "stat fps"
explanation: "stat game") display real-time performance metrics on screen
